awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Improving Our Understanding of Nitrous Oxide Emissions to the Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER award is supporting research to resolve key questions about the emissions of N2O (nitrous oxide) to the atmosphere.  Both observations and modeling will be used to help improve the understanding of how agricultural soils and surrounding waterways contribute to the global problem of rising N2O levels. The project includes activities and collaborations that bring interest in scientific research to K-12 students, particularly those who are under-represented in the sciences.

The two questions that are motivating and guiding the proposed investigation are:
1.	Why are state-of-the-art models and inventories unable to accurately reproduce regional scale N2O emissions?
2.	What are regional-scale controls on current and future N2O emissions in North America?

As part of this project, tower and aircraft measurements over soils and waterways encompassing natural and fertilized lands in the Corn Belt and along the lower Mississippi River basin will be combined with a regional Lagrangian transport model to determine contemporary emissions of N2O. Geostatistical modeling will be used to establish the statistical relationship between variables such as temperature, precipitation, inundation state, and soil moisture and regional emissions.

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER project aims to advance our understanding of nitrogen’s impact on climate and ozone destruction by improving our understanding on controls of the release of nitrous oxide to the atmosphere.  This project also has an outreach component designed to help address issues of persistent underrepresentation within the geosciences.  The primary science questions are: Why are state-of-the-art models and inventories unable to accurately reproduce regional-scale N2O emissions? What are regional-scale controls on current and future N2O emissions in North America?  To address these driving questions, we collected new airborne observations with custom instrumentation to accurately capture small variations in N2O caused by emission processes.  We used these flight observations in combination with mass balance and inverse model techniques, leveraging lagrangian particle dispersion models, to address the question of emissions magnitudes and controls in the central US.  This work has contributed to five peer-reviewed papers.  Major results included: 1) The development, testing, and demonstration of a continuous N2O analyzer suitable for flight operation, where a custom calibration scheme was devised that could address sensitivity of instruments to flight conditions that can be used more widely by laser spectroscopy-based instruments for trace gas detection (Gvakharia et al., 2018, doi: 10.5194/amt-11-6059-2018). 2) The evaluation of cropland and fertilizer plant emissions across the Mississippi River Valley, including the first quantification of N2O emissions at the regional scale in this domain as well as the first airborne quantification of N2O emission from fertilizer plants (Gvakharia et al., 2020 doi: https://doi.org/10.1029/2020JD032815). Further, this work demonstrated the ability of aircraft to sample and determine emissions variations at the farm scale.  Cumulatively, the work has highlighted the value of airborne measurements as being uniquely suited to sample the spatial variability of N2O emissions and provide key insights into processes controlling those emissions.  Multiple graduate students (and 1 undergraduate and 1 research scientist) received training under this project, including 1 PhD thesis. Broader outreach included the partnership with Iridescent (now called Technovation), with the creation of a design challenge (https://www.curiositymachine.org/challenges/162/) for use across the nation, as well as our multi-year involvement in the GISE (Girls in Science & Engineering) summer camp.
